security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing no executable code. All content is educational markdown with code examples for legitimate Telegram development. No scripts, network calls, file system access, or command execution capabilities exist in the skill files.

content.user_title: Build Telegram Bots and Mini Apps
content.value_statement: Creating Telegram bots or web apps requires understanding Bot API, Mini Apps, and client development. This skill provides comprehensive guides for messaging, payments, webhooks, and interactive UI components.
actual_capabilities: Create Telegram bots with Bot API and messaging features
Build Mini Apps using Telegram WebApp JavaScript API
Implement interactive keyboards and inline buttons
Configure webhooks and long polling for updates
Integrate payments and handle callback queries
Format data displays for professional bot output
limitations: Does not provide executable code or scripts
No pre-built bot templates or deployment tools
Authentication requires separate Telegram account setup
External API integrations need separate implementation

prompt_templates.title: Basic Bot Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a Telegram bot using python-telegram-bot? Show me how to get the token from BotFather and write a simple bot that responds to /start and /help commands.

prompt_templates.title: Interactive Keyboards
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create inline keyboards and reply keyboards in a Telegram bot. How do I handle button clicks and callback queries?

prompt_templates.title: Mini App Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a Telegram Mini App? What JavaScript API does Telegram provide for accessing user data, theme parameters, and sending data back to the bot?

prompt_templates.title: Webhook Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to configure a webhook for a Telegram bot. What are the requirements for HTTPS, ports, and SSL certificates? Show a Flask example.

output_examples.input: Create a simple echo bot that replies with the same message user sends
output: 3. Create bot.py with your token and handlers
4. The bot will echo any text message back to the user

best_practices: Validate all incoming data server-side, especially initData from Mini Apps
Use webhooks for production deployments instead of long polling
Store bot tokens in environment variables, never commit to version control
anti_patterns: Hardcoding bot tokens or API credentials in source code
Trusting client-side data without server-side verification
Ignoring rate limits causing bot account restrictions

faq.question: What programming languages are supported for Telegram bot development?
faq.answer: Python (python-telegram-bot, aiogram), JavaScript (node-telegram-bot-api, Telegraf, grammY), PHP, Go, Java, and C# all have supported libraries.

faq.question: What are the rate limits for Telegram bots?
faq.answer: Group messages: 20 per minute, private chats: 30 per second. Exceeding limits temporarily blocks the bot.

faq.question: How do Mini Apps communicate with bots?
faq.answer: Mini Apps use tg.sendData() to send JSON strings to the bot, which receives them as callback data in webhook or polling updates.

faq.question: Is my bot data safe in Mini Apps?
faq.answer: Always validate initData using HMAC-SHA256 with your bot token. Never trust data sent from the client without verification.

faq.question: Why is my webhook not receiving updates?
faq.answer: Check HTTPS certificate validity, verify public URL accessibility, ensure ports 443/80/88/8443 are open, and confirm the endpoint returns HTTP 200 quickly.

faq.question: What is the difference between Bot API and MTProto?
faq.answer: Bot API is HTTP-based for bot accounts only. MTProto is the native Telegram protocol for user accounts with full feature access via TDLib libraries.
